meanings.definition: To walk unsteadily, typically due to injury or weakness.
meanings.sent1: After hurting his leg, he had to hobble slowly to the doctor's office.
meanings.sent2: The injured puppy could only hobble around the yard.
meanings.sent3: The hobbling squirrel tried to climb the tree but kept slipping down comically.
meanings.sent4: Her sprained ankle made her feel like she was trying to hobble through quicksand.
meanings.sent5: The old man's hobbling gait was a testament to his years of hard work.

meanings.definition: A device used to restrain the movement of a horse by tying its legs together.
meanings.sent1: The cowboy used a hobble to keep the horse from wandering off.
meanings.sent2: The stable had several hobbles hanging on the wall.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous foal managed to undo the hobble and gallop freely in the field.
meanings.sent4: The hobble on the horse's leg looked like a shackle from a distance.
meanings.sent5: The old leather hobble showed signs of wear from years of use.

meanings.definition: To impede or hinder the progress or movement of something.
meanings.sent1: The heavy traffic will hobble our journey to the beach.
meanings.sent2: A lack of funding could hobble the construction project.
meanings.sent3: The villain's plan to hobble the hero's efforts backfired spectacularly.
meanings.sent4: Her fear of failure seemed to hobble her ability to take risks.
meanings.sent5: The thick mud threatened to hobble the progress of the hikers.
